           Ã‚Â°        In Norway, singer-songwriter Kari Bremnes        Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        needs no introduction.  For those of us in       Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        North America, Ms Bremnes could be called        Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        a Norwegian Joni Mitchell with her blend         Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        of folk, jazz and blues or a Nordic Carol        Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        King when she sings in her sultry voice          Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        backed by moody piano and arrangement of         Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        instruments.  One of the tracks, Always          Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        Loved the Fall on her latest CD, "Over en        Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        by" (Above the City), sums up the                Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        atmosphere of this recording.  The CD            Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        contains a collection of songs that if not       Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        lyrically, at least musically reflect on         Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        the autumn years of one&#039;s life and the           Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        recording&#039;s timbre feels like a brisk            Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        autumn day, somewhere between the late           Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        summer harvest and the impending winter          Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        chill.s                                          Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°                                                         Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        According to the press notes, "The songs         Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        on her new album reveal the artist&#039;s             Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        uncompromising approach to content and           Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        style, and often break away from the             Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        traditional form of verse following              Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        refrain."  She works with a band of              Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        Kirkelig Kulturverksted regulars that            Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        includes guitarist Knut Reiersrud, bassist       Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        Bjorn Kjellemyr, drummer Helge Nordbakken,       Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        keyboardist Bengt Egil Hansen and guest          Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        musicians on trumpet, fiddle and guitar.         Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        The repertoire for the most part range           Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        from moody to melancholy and the sound           Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        possesses an end-of-summer or a rainy day        Ã‚Â°
           Ã‚Â°        pensiveness.                                     Ã‚Â°
